{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Christine de Pizan | image = Christine de Pisan - cathedra.jpg | caption = Christine de Pizan giving a lecture | birth_date = 11 September 1364 | birth_place = [[Republic of Venice|Venice]] | death_date = [[Circa|c.]] {{death year and age|1430|1364}} | death_place = | education = | occupation = Writer | spouse = Etienne du Castel | parents = Tommaso di Benvenuto da Pizzano | children = Jean du Castel }} '''Christine de Pizan''' (also seen as '''de Pisan'''; {{IPA-fr|kʁistin də pizɑ̃|-|Fr-Christine De Pisan.ogg}} ; 1364 – c. 1430) was an Italian and French author. She is best remembered for defending women in ''[[The Book of the City of Ladies]]'' and ''[[The Treasure of the City of Ladies]]''. Pizan was a prominent moralist and political thinker in [[medieval France]]. Pizan's patrons included [[Louis I, Duke of Orléans|Louis of Orleans]], [[Philip the Bold]] and [[John the Fearless]]. She served as a court writer during the reign of [[Charles VI of France|Charles VI]]. Her books of advice to princesses, princes and knights remained in print until the 16th century.
In recent decades, Pizan's work has been returned to prominence by the efforts of scholars such as Charity Cannon Willard, Earl Jeffrey Richards and [[Simone de Beauvoir]].
== Family == Christine de Pizan was born 1364 in [[Republic of Venice|Venice]], Italy. She was the daughter of Tommaso di Benvenuto da Pizzano. Her father became known as Thomas de Pizan, named for the family's origins in the town of Pizzano, south east of [[Bologna]]. Her father worked as a physician, court astrologer, and Councillor of the [[Republic of Venice]].<ref>Christine de Pizan, The Book of the City of Ladies, trans. by Rosalind Brown-Grant (London: Penguin Books, 1999), introduction.</ref> Thomas de Pizan accepted an appointment to the court of [[Charles V of France]] as the king's [[astrologer]]<ref name="Redfern, p. 77">Redfern, Jenny, "Christine de Pisan and The Treasure of the City of Ladies: A Medieval Rhetorician and Her Rhetoric" in Lunsford, Andrea A, ed. ''Reclaiming Rhetorica: Women and in the Rhetorical Tradition'', Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press, 1995, p. 77.</ref> and in 1368 Pizan moved to Paris. In 1379 Pizan married the notary and royal secretary Etienne du Castel.<ref name="Margaret C. Schaus 2006 133">{{cite book |author=Margaret C. Schaus|title=Women and Gender in Medieval Europe: An Encyclopedia |publisher= Routledge|date=2006 |pages=133|isbn= 978-1-135-45960-4 }}</ref>
She had three children. Her daughter became a nun at the Dominican Abbey in Poissy in 1397 as a companion to the King's daughter [[Marie of Valois, Prioress of Poissy|Marie]].<ref>Charity C. Willard, Christine de Pizan: Her Life and Works (New York: Persea Books, 1984, p. 35.</ref> Pizan's husband died of the [[Plague (disease)|plague]] in 1389, her father had died the year before.<ref name="Margaret C. Schaus 2006 133"/> Pizan was left to support her mother and her children.<ref>Pizan, ed. by Brown-Grant, introduction.</ref> When she tried to collect money from her husband's estate, she faced complicated lawsuits regarding the recovery of salary due her husband.<ref name="Willard, p. 39">Charity C. Willard, Christine de Pizan: Her Life and Works (New York: Persea Books, 1984, p. 39.</ref> On 4 June 1389, in a judgment concerning a lawsuit filed against her by the archbishop of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Sens|Sens]] and François Chanteprime, councillors of the King, Christine was styled "damoiselle" and widow of "Estienne du Castel".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Audouin Chauveron|last=Famiglietti|first=R.C.|publisher=|isbn=|volume=2 |year=2015 |page=261}}</ref>
== Writing career ==
In order to support herself and her family, Christine turned to writing. By 1393, she was writing love [[ballads]], which caught the attention of wealthy patrons within the court.<ref name="Redfern, p. 77" /> Pizan became a prolific writer. Her involvement in the production of her books and her skilful use of patronage in turbulent political times has earned her the title of the first professional woman of letters in Europe.<ref name="Margaret C. Schaus 2006 133"/> Although Italian by birth, Pizan expressed fervent nationalism for France. Affective and financially she attached to the royal family of France. She gifted or dedicated her early ballades to members of the royal family, such as [[Isabeau of Bavaria]], [[Louis I, Duke of Orléans]], and [[Marie of Berry]]. Of Queen Isabeau she wrote in 1402 "High, excellent crowned Queen of France, very redoubtable princess, powerful lady, born at a lucky hour".<ref>{{cite book |last=Langdon Forhan |first=Kate |title=The Political Theory of Christine de Pizan |publisher=Taylor & Francis |date=2017 |pages=68 |isbn=978-1-351-88394-8 }}</ref>
[[File:Queen Penthesilea Harley 4431 Pizan.png|thumb|right|A miniature of Queen [[Penthesilea]] with her army of [[Amazons]] coming to the aid of the [[Troy|Trojan]] army, illustrating ''L'Épître Othéa a Hector''.<ref name="British Library">{{cite web|url= http://blogs.bl.uk/digitisedmanuscripts/2013/06/christine-de-pizan-and-the-book-of-the-queen.html |title= Christine de Pizan and the Book of the Queen|date= 27 June 2013|publisher= British Library|access-date=3 June 2018}}</ref>]] [[File:Pisan lelivredestroisvertus.jpg|thumb|right|One page of Pizan's book ''Le livre des trois vertus''. In the illumination Pizan is kept from rest by the Three Virtues.]] France was ruled by [[Charles VI of France|Charles VI]] who experienced a series of mental breakdowns, causing a crisis of leadership for the French monarchy.<ref name="Margaret C. Schaus 2006 133"/> He was often absent from court and could eventually only make decisions with the approval of a royal council.<ref>{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=5|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> Queen Isabeau was nominally in charge of governance when her husband was absent from court, but could not extinguish the quarrel between members of the royal family.<ref>{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=14|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> In the past, [[Blanche of Castile]] had played a central role in the stability of the royal court and had acted as regent of France. Pizan published a series of works on the virtues of women, referencing Queen Blanche and dedicating them to Queen Isabeau.<ref name="Karen Green 2010 6">{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=6|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref><ref name="Tracy Adams 2014 115–116">{{cite book |author=Tracy Adams|title=Christine de Pizan and the Fight for France|publisher= Penn State Press|date=2014 |pages=115–116|isbn= 978-0-271-06633-2}}</ref>
Pizan believed that France had been founded by the descendants of the [[Troy|Trojans]] and that its governance by the royal family adhered to the [[Aristotelianism|Aristotelian]] ideal.<ref>{{cite book |last=Langdon Forhan |first=Kate |title=The Political Theory of Christine de Pizan |publisher= Taylor & Francis |date=2017 |pages=71|isbn= 978-1-351-88394-8 }}</ref> In 1400 Pizan published ''L'Épistre de Othéa a Hector'' (''Letter of Othea to Hector'').<ref name="Langdon Forhan 2017 34">{{cite book |last=Langdon Forhan |first=Kate |title=The Political Theory of Christine de Pizan |publisher= Taylor & Francis |date=2017 |pages=34|isbn= 978-1-351-88394-8 }}</ref> When first published, the book was dedicated to [[Louis I, Duke of Orléans|Louis of Orléans]], the brother of Charles VI, who was at court seen as potential regent of France.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page= 20|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> In ''L'Épistre de Othéa a Hector'' [[Hector of Troy]] is tutored in statecraft and the political virtues by the goddess of wisdom Othéa.<ref name="Langdon Forhan 2017 34"/> Pizan produced richly illustrated luxury editions of ''L'Épistre de Othéa a Hector'' in 1400.<ref>{{cite book |author=Margaret C. Schaus|title=Women and Gender in Medieval Europe: An Encyclopedia |publisher= Routledge|date=2006 |pages=134|isbn= 978-1-135-45960-4 }}</ref> Between 1408 and 1415 Pizan produced further editions of the book.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page=20|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> Throughout her career she produced rededicated editions of the book with customised prologues for patrons,<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page=198|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> including an edition for [[Philip the Bold]] in 1403, and editions for [[Jean de Berry|Jean of Berry]] and [[Henry IV of England]] in 1404.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page=|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> [[Patronage]] changed in the late [[Middle Ages]]. Texts were still produced and circulated as continuous roll [[manuscript culture|manuscripts]], but were increasingly replaced by the bound [[codex]]. Members of royal family became patrons of writers by commissioning books. As materials became cheaper a book trade developed, so writers and bookmakers produced books for the French nobility, who could afford to establish their own [[libraries]]. Pizan thus had no single patron who consistently supported her financially and became associated with the royal court and the different fractions of the royal family – the Burgundy, Orleans and Berry – each having their own respective courts.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |pages=197|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> Throughout her career Pizan undertook concurrent paid projects for individual patrons and subsequently published these works for dissemination among the nobility of France.<ref name="University of Minnesota Press">{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |pages=198|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref>
In 1402 Pizan became involved in a renowned literary controversy, the "Querelle du Roman de la Rose".<ref>Charity C. Willard, Christine de Pizan: Her Life and Works (New York: Persea Books, 1984), p.73</ref> Pizan instigated this debate by questioning the literary merits of [[Jean de Meun]]'s popular ''[[Roman de la Rose|Romance of the Rose]]''. ''Romance of the Rose'' satirizes the conventions of courtly love while critically depicting women as nothing more than seducers.<ref>Maureen Quilligan, The Allegory of Female Authority: Christine de Pizan's "Cité des Dames" (New York: Cornell University Press, 1991), p. 40.</ref> In the midst of the [[Hundred Years' War]] between French and English kings,<ref name="Margaret C. Schaus 2006 133"/> Pizan published the [[dream allegory]] ''[[Le Chemin de long estude]]'' in 1403. In the first person narrative she and [[Cumaean Sibyl]] travel together and witness a debate on the state of the world between the four [[allegories]] – [[Wealth]], [[Nobility]], [[Chivalry]] and [[Wisdom]].<ref>{{cite book |first1=Barbara K. |last1=Altmann |first2=Deborah L. |last2=McGrady |title=Christine de Pizan: A Casebook |publisher= Routledge |date=2003 |pages=11|isbn= 978-0-415-93909-6 }}</ref> Pizan suggests that [[justice]] could be brought to earth by a single monarch who had the necessary qualities.<ref>{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=26|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref>
In 1404 Pizan chronicled the life of Charles V, portraying him as the ideal king and political leader, in ''Le Livre des fais et bonnes meurs du sage roy Charles V''.<ref name="Langdon Forhan 2017 34"/> The chronical had been commissioned by [[Philip the Bold]]<ref name="Karen Green 2010 11">{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=11|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> and in the chronicle Pizan passed judgement on the state of the royal court. When praising the efforts of Charles V in studying [[Latin]], Pizan lamented that her contemporaries had to resort to strangers to read the [[law]] to them.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page=26|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> Before the book was completed, Philip the Bold died, and Pizan offered the book to Jean of Berry in 1405, finding a new royal patron.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page=27|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> She was paid 100 livre for the book by Philip's successor [[John the Fearless]] in 1406 and would receive payments from his court for books until 1412.<ref name="University of Minnesota Press"/>
In 1405 Pizan published ''Le Livre de la cité des dames'' (''[[The Book of the City of Ladies]]'') and ''Le Livre des trois vertus'' (''Book of Three Virtues'', known as ''[[The Treasure of the City of Ladies]]'').<ref name="Tracy Adams 2014 115–116"/> In ''Le Livre de la cité des dames'' Pizan presented intellectual and royal female leaders, such as [[Queen Zenobia]].<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page=29|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> Pizan dedicated ''Le Livre des trois vertus'' to the dauphine [[Margaret of Nevers]], advising the young princess on what she had to learn.<ref name="Tracy Adams 2014 115–116"/> As Queen Isabeau's oldest son [[Louis of Guyenne]] came of age Pizan addressed three works to him with the intention of promoting wise and effective government. The earliest of the three works has been lost. In ''Livre du Corps de policie'' (''The Book of the Body Politic''), published in 1407 and dedicated to the dauphin,<ref name="Karen Green 2010 6"/> Pizan set out a political treatises which analysed and described the customs and governments of [[Middle Ages|late medieval European]] societies. Pizan favoured hereditary monarchies, arguing in reference to Italian [[city-state]]s that were governed by princes or trades, that "such governance is not profitable at all for the common good".<ref>{{cite book |last=Langdon Forhan |first=Kate |title=The Political Theory of Christine de Pizan |publisher= Taylor & Francis |date=2017 |pages=70|isbn= 978-1-351-88394-8 }}</ref> Pizan also devoted several chapters to the duties of a king as military leader and she described in detail the role of the military class in society.<ref name="Penn State Press">{{cite book |first1=Charity Cannon |last1=Willard |first2=Sumner |last2=Willard |chapter=Preface |title=Book of Deeds of Arms and of Chivalry |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |page=5|isbn= 978-0-271-04305-0 }}</ref>
=== Civil war === France was at the verge of all out civil war since 1405.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |first1=Charity Cannon |last1=Willard |first2=Sumner |last2=Willard |chapter=Preface |title=Book of Deeds of Arms and of Chivalry |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |page=3|isbn= 978-0-271-04305-0 }}</ref> In 1407 [[John I of Burgundy]], also known as John the Fearless, plunged France into a crisis when he had Louis of Orléans assassinated.<ref name="Karen Green 2010 6"/> The Duke of Burgundy fled Paris when his complicity in the assassination became known,<ref name="ReferenceA"/> but was appointed regent of France on behalf of Charles VI<ref>{{cite book |last=Whetham |first=David |title=Just Wars and Moral Victories: Surprise, Deception and the Normative Framework of European War in the Later Middle Ages |publisher= BRILL |date=2009 |pages=61|isbn= 9789004171534 }}</ref> in late 1408 after his military victory in the [[Battle of Othee]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> It is not certain who commissioned Pizan to write a treatise on military warfare,<ref name="Karen Green 2010 13">{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=13|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> but in 1410 Pizan published the manual on [[chivalry]], entitled ''Livre des fais d'armes et de chevalerie'' (''The Book of Feats of Arms and of Chivalry'').<ref>{{cite book |first=Jennifer R. |last=Goodman |title=Chivalry and Exploration, 1298–1630 |publisher=Boydell & Brewer |location=Woodbridge |date=1998 |pages=147|isbn= 978-0-85115-700-9 }}</ref> Pizan received 200 livre from the royal treasury in early 1411 for the book.<ref name="Penn State Press"/> In the preface Pizan explained that she published the manual in French so that it could be read by practitioners of war not well versed in Latin. The book opened with a discussion of the [[just war theory]] advanced by [[Honoré Bonet]]. Pizan also referenced classical writers on military warfare, such as [[Vegetius]], [[Frontinus]] and [[Valerius Maximus]].<ref name="Whetham 2009 62–63">{{cite book |last=Whetham |first=David |title=Just Wars and Moral Victories: Surprise, Deception and the Normative Framework of European War in the Later Middle Ages |publisher= BRILL |date=2009 |pages=62–63|isbn= 9789004171534 }}</ref> Pizan discussed contemporary matters relating to what she termed the ''Laws of War'', such as [[capital punishment]], the payment of troops, as well as the treatment of [[noncombatants]] and [[prisoners of war]]. Pizan opposed [[trial by combat]],<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite book |first1=Charity Cannon |last1=Willard |first2=Sumner |last2=Willard |chapter=Preface |title=Book of Deeds of Arms and of Chivalry |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |page=7|isbn= 978-0-271-04305-0 }}</ref> but articulated the medieval belief that God is the lord and governor of battle and that wars are the proper execution of justice. Nevertheless she acknowledged that in a war "many great wrongs, extortions, and grievous deeds are committed, as well as raping, killings, forced executions, and arsons".<ref name="Whetham 2009 62–63"/> Pizan limited the right to wage war to sovereign kings because as head of states they were responsible for the welfare of their subjects.<ref>{{cite book |first1=Charity Cannon |last1=Willard |first2=Sumner |last2=Willard |chapter=Preface |title=Book of Deeds of Arms and of Chivalry |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |page=6|isbn= 978-0-271-04305-0 }}</ref> In 1411 the royal court published an edict prohibiting nobles from raising an army.<ref name="Karen Green 2010 13"/>
After civil war had broken out in France, Pizan in 1413 offered guidance to the young dauphin on how to govern well, publishing ''Livre de la paix'' (''The Book of Peace'').<ref name="978-0-8028-3347-1 p.654">{{cite book |last=Allen |first=Prudence |title=The Concept of Woman: The Early Humanist Reformation, 1250–1500, Part 2 |publisher= Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing |date=2005 |pages=654|isbn= 978-0-8028-3347-1 }}</ref> ''Livre de la paix'' would be Pizan's last major work and contained detailed formulations of her thoughts on good governance.<ref>{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=4|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> The period was marked by bouts of civil war and failed attempts to bring John the Fearless to justice for assassinating his cousin. Pizan addressed Louis of Guyenne directly, encouraging him to continue the quest for peace in France.<ref name="Karen Green 2010 6"/> She argued that "Every kingdom divided in itself will be made desolate, and every city and house divided against itself will not stand".<ref name="Karen Green 2010 7">{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=7|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> Pizan was acquainted with [[William of Tignonville]], an ambassador to the royal court, and referenced Tignonville's speeches on the [[Armagnac–Burgundian Civil War]].<ref name="Karen Green 2010 7"/> Pizan's drew a utopian vision of a just ruler, who could take advice from those older or wiser. In arguing that peace and justice were possible on earth as well as in heaven, Pizan was influenced by [[Dante]],<ref>{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=24|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> who she had referenced in ''[[Le Chemin de long estude]]''.<ref>{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=25|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> Pizan encouraged the dauphin to deserve respect, by administering justice promptly and living by worthy example. Pizan urged young princes to make themselves available to their subjects, avoid anger and cruelty, to act liberally, clement and truthful. Pizan's interpretation of the virtuous Christian prince built on the advice to rulers by [[St Benedict]], [[Peter Abelard]] and [[Cicero]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=28|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref>
[[File:Christine de Pisan and Queen Isabeau detail.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Christine de Pizan presents her book to [[Isabeau of Bavaria]], Queen of France.]] In 1414 Pizan presented Queen Isabeau with a lavishly decorated collection of her works (now known as ''British Library Harley 4431'').<ref name="Karen Green 2010 11"/> The bound book contained 30 of Pizan's writings and 130 miniatures.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |pages=195|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> She had been asked by the queen to produce the book. Noted for its quality miniature illuminations, Pizan herself and her past royal patrons were depicted. As a mark of ownership and [[author]]ship the opening frontispiece depicted Queen Isabeau being presented with the book by Pizan.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page=203|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref>
In 1418 Pizan published a consolation for women who had lost family members in the [[Battle of Agincourt]] under the title ''Epistre de la prison de vie Humaine'' (''Letter Concerning the Prison of Human Life'').<ref name="978-0-8028-3347-1 p.654"/> In it Pizan did not express any optimism or hope that peace could be found on earth. Instead she expressed the view that the [[soul]] was trapped in the body and imprisoned in [[hell]]. The previous year she had presented the ''Epistre de la prison de vie Humaine'' to [[Marie of Berry]],<ref name="Karen Green 2010 27">{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=27|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> the administrator of the [[Duchy of Bourbon]] whose husband was held in English captivity.<ref>{{cite book |author=Tracy Adams|title=Christine de Pizan and the Fight for France|publisher= Penn State Press|date=2014 |pages=169|isbn= 978-0-271-06633-2}}</ref>
Historians assume that Pizan spent the last ten years of her life in the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] Convent of Poissy because of the civil war and the occupation of Paris by the English.<ref name="978-0-8028-3347-1 p.654"/> Away from the royal court her literary activity dried up.<ref name="Margaret C. Schaus 2006 133"/> However, in 1429, after [[Joan of Arc]]'s military victory over the English, Pizan published the poem ''Ditié de Jehanne d'Arc'' (''The Tale of Joan of Arc'').<ref name="978-0-8028-3347-1 p.654" /> Published just a few days after the coronation of [[Charles VII of France|Charles VII]], Pizan expressed renewed optimism. She cast Arc as the fulfilment of prophecies by [[Merlin]], [[Cumaean Sibyl]] and [[Saint Bede]], helping Charles VII to fulfil the predictions of [[Charlemagne]].<ref name="Karen Green 2010 27"/>
Pizan is believed to have died in 1430, before Arc was trialled and executed by the English.<ref name="Margaret C. Schaus 2006 133"/> After her death the political crisis in France was resolved when Queen Isabeau's only surviving son [[Charles VII of France|Charles VII]] and John the Fearless' successor as Duke of Burgundy, [[Philip the Good]], signed the [[Treaty of Arras (1435)|Peace of Arras]] in 1435.<ref name="Karen Green 2010 6"/>
== Works == [[File:Harley MS 4431 knights jousting Pizan.png|thumb|300px|right|Detail of a miniature of ladies watching [[knights]] [[jousting]], illustrating 'Le Duc des vrais amants', from a collection of works presented in 1414 by Pizan to [[Isabeau of Bavaria]].<ref name="British Library"/>]] [[File:Meister der 'Cité des Dames' 002.jpg|thumb|300px|right|upright=1.2|[[Illuminated manuscript|Illumination]] from ''[[The Book of the City of Ladies]]''. Pizan is shown before the personifications of Rectitude, Reason, and Justice in her study, and helping another lady to build the 'Cité des dames'.<ref name="British Library"/>]]
Pizan produced a large number of vernacular works, in both prose and verse. Her works include political treatises, [[mirrors for princes]], epistles, and poetry.
Pizan's book ''Le Dit de la Rose'' (''The Tale of the Rose'') was published in 1402 as a direct attack on [[Jean de Meun]]'s extremely popular book ''Romance of the Rose'' which characterised women as seducers. Pizan claimed that Meun's views were misogynistic, vulgar, immoral, and slanderous to women. The exchange between the two authors involved them sending each other their treatises, defending their respective views. At the height of the exchange Pizan published ''Querelle du Roman de la Rose'' (''Letters on the Debate of the Rose'').<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/place_settings/christine_de_pisan |title=Christine de Pisan|website= Brooklyn Museum |publisher= Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art |access-date=18 Nov 2017}}</ref> In this particular apologetic response, Pizan belittles her own writing style, employing a rhetorical strategy by writing against the grain of her meaning, also known as [[antiphrasis]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Redfern |first=Jenny |chapter=Christine de Pisan and the Treasure of the City of Ladies: a medieval rhetorician and her rhetoric |editor-last=Lunsford |editor-first=Andrea A. |title=Reclaiming Rhetorica: Women and in the Rhetorical Tradition |location=Pittsburgh |publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press |year=1995 |page=80 }}</ref>
By 1405 Pizan had completed her most famous literary works, ''[[The Book of the City of Ladies]]'' (''Le Livre de la cité des dames'') and ''[[The Treasure of the City of Ladies]]'' (''Le Livre des trois vertus''). The first of these shows the importance of women's past contributions to society, and the second strives to teach women of all estates how to cultivate useful qualities.<ref>Charity C. Willard, Christine de Pizan: Her Life and Works (New York: Persea Books, 1984, p.135</ref>
In ''The Book of the City of Ladies'' Pizan created a symbolic city in which women are appreciated and defended. She constructed three allegorical figures – Reason, Justice, and Rectitude – in the common pattern of literature in that era, when many books and poetry utilized stock allegorical figures to express ideas or emotions. She enters into a dialogue, a movement between question and answer, with these allegorical figures that is from a completely female perspective.<ref>Campbell, Karlyn K., Three Tall Women: Radical Challenges to Criticism, Pedagogy, and Theory, The Carroll C. Arnold Distinguished Lecture National Communication Association November 2001 Boston: Pearson Education Inc, 2003, p. 6</ref> Together, they create a forum to speak on issues of consequence to all women. Only female voices, examples and opinions provide evidence within this text. Through Lady Reason in particular Pizan argues that stereotypes of women can be sustained only if women are prevented from entering into the conversation.<ref>Campbell, Karlyn K., Three Tall Women: Radical Challenges to Criticism, Pedagogy, and Theory, The Carroll C. Arnold Distinguished Lecture National Communication Association November 2001 Boston: Pearson Education Inc, 2003, p. 7</ref>
In ''City of Ladies'' Pizan deliberated on the debate whether the virtues of men and women differ, a frequently debated topic in late [[medieval Europe]], particularly in the context of [[Aristotelian ethics|Aristotelian virtue ethics]] and his [[Aristotle's views on women|views on women]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Bejczy |first=Istvan P. |editor-first1=Karen|editor-last1=Green|editor-first2=Constant|editor-last2=Mews |title=Virtue Ethics for Women 1250–1500 |publisher=Springer |date=2011 |pages=1–2 |chapter=Chapter 1: Does Virtue Recognise Gender? Christine de Pizan's City of Ladies in the Light of Scholastic Debate |isbn=9789400705296 }}</ref> Pizan repeatedly used the theological argument that men and women are created in God's image and both have souls capable of embracing God's goodness. Among the inhabitants of the ''City of Ladies'' are female saints, women from the [[Old Testament]] and virtuous women from the pagan antiquity as portrait by [[Giovanni Boccaccio]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Bejczy |first=Istvan P. |editor-first1=Karen|editor-last1=Green|editor-first2=Constant|editor-last2=Mews |title=Virtue Ethics for Women 1250–1500 |publisher=Springer |date=2011 |pages=10–11 |chapter=Chapter 1: Does Virtue Recognise Gender? Christine de Pizan's City of Ladies in the Light of Scholastic Debate |isbn=9789400705296 }}</ref>
In ''The Treasure of the City of Ladies'' Pizan addressed the "community" of women with the stated objective of instructing them in the means of achieving [[virtue]]. She took the position that all women were capable of humility, diligence and moral rectitude, and that duly educated all women could become worthy residents of the imaginary ''City of Ladies''. Drawing on her own life, Pizan advised women on how to navigate the perils of early 15th century French society.<ref>{{cite book |last=Redfern |first=Jenny R. |editor-first=Andrea A. |editor-last=Lunsford |title=Virtue Ethics for Women 1250–1500 |publisher= University of Pittsburgh Press |date=1955 |pages=73 |chapter=Chapter 5: The Treasure of the City of Ladies: A Medieval Rhetorical and Her Rhetoric |isbn= 978-0-8229-7165-8 }}</ref> With reference to [[Augustine of Hippo]] and other saints Pizan offered advice on how the noble lady could achieve the love of God. Pizan speaks through the allegorical figures of God's daughters – Reason, Rectitude and Justice – who represent the Three Virtues most important to women's success. Through secular examples of these three virtues, Pizan urged women to discover meaning and achieve worthy acts in their lives. Pizan argued that women's success depends on their ability to manage and mediate by speaking and writing effectively.<ref>{{cite book |last=Redfern |first=Jenny R. |editor-first=Andrea A.|editor-last=Lunsford |title=Virtue Ethics for Women 1250–1500 |publisher= University of Pittsburgh Press |date=1955 |pages=74 |chapter=Chapter 5: The Treasure of the City of Ladies: A Medieval Rhetorical and Her Rhetoric |isbn= 978-0-8229-7165-8 }}</ref>
Pizan specifically sought out other women to collaborate in the creation of her work. She makes special mention of a manuscript illustrator we know only as [[Anastasia (artist)|Anastasia]], whom she described as the most talented of her day.<ref>[http://www.ripleyonline.com/Under%20Discussion/Christine/Christine.htm Christine de Pizan: An illuminated Voice] By Doré Ripley, 2004 Accessed October 2007</ref>
== Influence == [[File:Queen Fredegund addressing her troops City of Ladies 1475.png|thumb|250px|right|Queen [[Fredegund]] addressing her troops holding her baby. Miniature from a 1475 Dutch translation of ''The Book of the City of Ladies''. Published under the title ''De Stede der Vrouwen'' (''The Praise of Women'').<ref>{{cite web|url= http://blogs.bl.uk/digitisedmanuscripts/2017/03/index.html |title= The medieval origins of Mothering Sunday| date= 26 March 2017|publisher= British Library|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>]] [[File:Page 1 The Book of Feats of Arms and of Chivalry eng.png|thumb|250px|right|Page 1 of ''The Book of Feats of Arms and of Chivalry''. Translated into English and printed in 1489 by [[William Caxton]].]] Pizan published 41 known pieces of poetry and prose in her lifetime and she gained fame across Europe as the first professional woman writer. She achieved such credibility that royalty commissioned her prose and contemporary intellectuals kept copies of her works in their libraries.<ref>{{cite book |last=Redfern |first=Jenny R. |editor-first=Andrea A.|editor-last=Lunsford |title=Virtue Ethics for Women 1250–1500 |publisher= University of Pittsburgh Press |date=1955 |pages=74–75 |chapter=Chapter 5: The Treasure of the City of Ladies: A Medieval Rhetorical and Her Rhetoric |isbn= 978-0-8229-7165-8 }}</ref>
After her death in 1430 Pizan's influence was acknowledged by a variety of authors and her writings remained popular. Her book ''[[Le Livre de la cité des dames]]'' remained in print. Portuguese and Dutch editions of it exist from the 15th century, and French editions were still being printed in 1536.<ref name="978-0-8229-7165-8 p.75">{{cite book |last=Redfern |first=Jenny R. |editor-first=Andrea A.|editor-last=Lunsford |title=Virtue Ethics for Women 1250–1500 |publisher= University of Pittsburgh Press |date=1955 |pages=75 |chapter=Chapter 5: The Treasure of the City of Ladies: A Medieval Rhetorical and Her Rhetoric |isbn= 978-0-8229-7165-8 }}</ref> In 1521 ''The Book of the City of Ladies'' was published in English.<ref name="978-0-8229-7165-8 p.75"/> Pizan's ''Le Livre des trois vertus'' (''[[The Treasure of the City of Ladies]]'') became an important reference point for royal women in the 15th and 16th century. [[Anne of France]], who acted as regent of France, used it as a basis for her 1504 book of ''Enseignemens'', written for her daughter [[Suzanne, Duchess of Bourbon|Suzanne Duchess of Bourbon]], who as agnatic heir to the Bourbon lands became co-regent. Pizan's advice to princesses was translated and circulated as manuscript or printed book among the royal families of France and Portugal.<ref>{{cite book |editor= Marilynn Desmond |title=Christine de Pizan and the Categories of Difference|publisher= University of Minnesota Press |date=1998 |page=34|isbn= 978-0-8166-3081-3 }}</ref> The ''City of Ladies'' was acknowledged and referenced by 16th century French women writers, including [[Anne de Beaujeu]], [[Gabrielle de Bourbon]], [[Marguerite de Navarre]] and [[Georgette de Montenay]].<ref name="Christine de Pizan: A Casebook">{{cite book |first1=Barbara K. |last1=Altmann |first2=Deborah L. |last2=McGrady |title=Christine de Pizan: A Casebook |publisher= Routledge |date=2003 |pages=57|isbn= 978-0-415-93909-6 }}</ref>
Pizan's political writings received some attention too. ''Livre de la paix'' was referenced by the humanist [[Gabriel Naudé]] and Pizan was given large entries in [[encyclopedia]]s by [[Denis Diderot]], [[Louis Moréri]] and [[Prosper Marchand]].<ref name="Christine de Pizan: A Casebook"/> In 1470 [[Jean V de Bueil]] reproduced Pizan's detailed accounts of the armies and material needed to defend a castle or town against a [[siege]] in ''Le Jouvence''.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> ''Livre des fais d'armes et de chevalerie'' was published in its entirety by the book printer [[Antoine Vérard]] in 1488, but Vérard claimed that it was his translation of [[Vegetius]].<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite book |first1=Charity Cannon |last1=Willard |first2=Sumner |last2=Willard |chapter=Preface |title=Book of Deeds of Arms and of Chivalry |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |page=1|isbn= 978-0-271-04305-0 }}</ref> Philippe Le Noir authored an abridged version of Pizan's book in 1527 under the title ''L'Arbre des Batailles et fleur de chevalerie'' (''The tree of battles and flower of chivalry'').<ref>{{cite book |first1=Charity Cannon |last1=Willard |first2=Sumner |last2=Willard |chapter=Preface |title=Book of Deeds of Arms and of Chivalry |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |page=2|isbn= 978-0-271-04305-0 }}</ref>
''Livre des fais d'armes et de chevalerie'' was translated into English by [[William Caxton]] for [[Henry VII of England|Henry VII]] in 1489 and was published under the title ''The Book of Feats of Arms and of Chivalry'' as print one year later,<ref>{{cite book |last=Whetham |first=David |title=Just Wars and Moral Victories: Surprise, Deception and the Normative Framework of European War in the Later Middle Ages |publisher= BRILL |date=2009 |pages=62|isbn= 9789004171534 }}</ref> attributing Pizan as author.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> English editions of ''The Book of the City of Ladies'' and ''Livre du corps de policie'' (''The Book of the Body Politic'') were printed in 1521 without referencing Pizan as the author. [[Elizabeth I]] had in her court library copies of ''The Book of the City of Ladies'', ''L'Épistre de Othéa a Hector'' (''Letter of Othea to Hector'') and ''The Book of Feats of Arms and of Chivalry''. Among the possessions of the English queen were tapestries with scenes from the ''City of Ladies''.<ref>{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=30–31|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref> However, when in the early 19th century Raimond Thomassy published an overview of Pizan's political writings, he noted that modern editions of these writings were not published and that as a political theorist Pizan was descending into obscurity.<ref name="Karen Green 2010 3">{{cite book |author=Karen Green|title=Preface – The Book of Peace |publisher= Penn State Press|date=2010 |pages=3|isbn= 978-0-271-04557-3 }}</ref>
While Pizan's mixture of [[classical philosophy]] and [[humanistic]] ideals was in line with the style of other popular authors at the time, her outspoken defence of women was an anomaly. In her works she vindicated women against popular misogynist texts, such as [[Ovid]]'s ''Art of Love'', [[Jean de Meun]]'s ''Romance of the Rose'' and [[Mathieu of Boulogne|Matheolus]]'s ''Lamentations''. Her activism has drawn the fascination of modern feminists.<ref name="978-0-8229-7165-8 p.75"/> [[Simone de Beauvoir]] wrote in 1949 that ''Épître au Dieu d'Amour'' was "the first time we see a woman take up her pen in defence of her sex".<ref>{{Cite book|last=Schneir|first=Miriam|title=Feminism: The Essential Historical Writings|publisher=Vintage Books|isbn=978-0-679-75381-0|year=1994}}</ref>
The 1979 artwork ''[[The Dinner Party]]'' features a place setting for Christine de Pizan.<ref>[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/place_settings Place Settings]. Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved on 2015-08-06.</ref> In the 1980s Sandra Hindman published a study of the political events reverenced in the illuminations of Pizan's published works.<ref name="Karen Green 2010 3"/>
== List of works == * ''Enseignements moraux'' (1395) * ''L'Épistre au Dieu d'amours'' (1399) * ''L'Épistre de Othéa a Hector'' (1399–1400) * ''Dit de la Rose'' (1402) * ''Cent Ballades d'Amant et de Dame, Virelays, Rondeaux'' (1402) * ''[[Le Chemin de long estude]]'' (1403) * ''Livre de la mutation de fortune'' (1403) * ''La Pastoure'' (1403) * ''Le Livre des fais et bonnes meurs du sage roy Charles V'' (1404) * ''[[Le Livre de la cité des dames]]'' (1405) * ''[[Le Livre des trois vertus]]'' (1405) * ''L'Avision de Christine'' (1405) * ''Livre du corps de policie'' (1407) * ''Livre des fais d'armes et de chevalerie'' (1410) * ''Livre de paix'' (1413) * ''Epistre de la prison de vie humaine'' (1418) * ''Ditié de Jehanne d'Arc'' (1429)

{{Infobox book | name = Critique of Pure Reason | title_orig = Critik {{noitalic|{{sup|a}}}} der reinen Vernunft | translator = ''[[#English translations|see below]]'' | image = Kant-KdrV-1781.png{{!}}border | caption = Title page of the 1781 edition | author = [[Immanuel Kant]] | country = Germany | language = German | subject = [[Metaphysics]] | published = 1781 | pages = 856 (first German edition)<ref>[http://de.wikisource.org/wiki/Seite:Kant_Critik_der_reinen_Vernunft_856.png German Wikisource]</ref> | isbn= |dewey= |congress= |oclc= | notes = {{sup|a}} ''Kritik'' in [[modern German]]. }} {{Immanuel Kant |width=22.0em}}
The '''''Critique of Pure Reason''''' ({{lang|de|Kritik der reinen Vernunft}}) is a 1781 book by the German philosopher [[Immanuel Kant]], in which the author seeks to determine the limits and scope of [[metaphysics]]. A heavily-revised second edition was published in 1787. Also referred to as Kant's "First Critique," it was followed by the ''[[Critique of Practical Reason]]'' (1788) and the ''[[Critique of Judgment]]'' (1790). In the preface to the first edition, Kant explains that by a "critique of pure reason" he means not "a critique of books and systems, but of the faculty of reason in general, in respect of all knowledge after which it may strive ''independently of all experience''" and that he aims to reach a decision about "the possibility or impossibility of metaphysics". The First Critique is often viewed as culminating several centuries of [[early modern philosophy|early-modern philosophy]], and inaugurating [[western philosophy#Late modern (19th-century)|modern philosophy]].
Kant builds on the work of [[Empiricism|empiricist]] philosophers such as [[John Locke]] and [[David Hume]], as well as [[Rationalism|rationalists]] such as [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]] and [[Christian Wolff (philosopher)|Christian Wolff]]. He expounds new ideas on the nature of [[space and time]], and tries to provide solutions to Hume's scepticism regarding human knowledge of the relation of cause and effect, and [[René Descartes]]' scepticism regarding knowledge of the external world. This is argued through the [[transcendental idealism]] of objects (as appearance) and their form of appearance. Kant regards the former "as mere representations and not as things in themselves", and the latter as "only sensible forms of our intuition, but not determinations given for themselves or conditions of objects as things in themselves". This grants the possibility of a priori knowledge, since objects as appearance "must conform to our cognition . . . which is to establish something about objects before they are given to us". Knowledge independent of experience Kant calls "''[[A priori knowledge|a priori]]''" knowledge, while knowledge obtained through experience is termed "''[[a posteriori]]''".{{sfn|Kant |1999 |p=A2/B2}} According to Kant, a proposition is ''a priori'' if it is necessary and universal. A proposition is necessary if it could not possibly be false, and so cannot be denied without contradiction. A proposition is universal if it is true in all cases, and so does not admit of any exceptions. Knowledge gained ''a posteriori'' through the senses, Kant argues, never imparts absolute necessity and universality, because it is always possible that we might encounter an exception.{{sfn|Kant |1999 |p=B4}}
Kant claims to have discovered another attribute of propositions: the distinction between [[Analytic–synthetic distinction|"analytic" and "synthetic" judgments]].{{sfn|Kant |1999 |loc=Introduction, Part IV, p. A6/B10}} According to Kant, a proposition is analytic if the content of the ''predicate-concept'' of the proposition is already contained within the ''subject-concept'' of that proposition.{{sfn|Kant |1999 |pp=A6–7/B10–11}} For example, Kant considers the proposition "All bodies are extended" analytic, since the predicate-concept ('extended') is already contained within—or "thought in"—the subject-concept of the sentence ('body'). The distinctive character of analytic judgements was therefore that they can be known to be true simply by an analysis of the concepts contained in them; they are true by definition. In synthetic propositions, on the other hand, the predicate-concept is not already contained within the subject-concept. For example, Kant considers the proposition "All bodies are heavy" synthetic, since the concept 'body' does not already contain within it the concept 'weight'.{{sfn|Kant |1999 |p=B12}} Synthetic judgments therefore add something to a concept, whereas analytic judgments only explain what is already contained in the concept.
Prior to Kant, it was thought that all ''a priori'' knowledge must be analytic. Kant, however, argues that our knowledge of mathematics, of the first principles of natural science, and of metaphysics, is both ''a priori'' and synthetic. The peculiar nature of this knowledge, Kant argues, cries out for explanation. The central problem of the ''Critique'' is therefore to answer the question: "How are synthetic ''a priori'' judgements possible?"{{sfn|Kant |1999 |p=B20}} It is a "matter of life and death" to metaphysics and to human reason, Kant argues, that the grounds of this kind of knowledge be explained.{{sfn|Kant |1999 |p=B20}}
Though it received little attention when it was first published, the ''Critique'' later attracted attacks from both empiricist and rationalist critics, and became a source of controversy. It has exerted an enduring influence on [[Western philosophy]], and helped to bring about the development of [[German idealism]].
==Background: early rationalism and Kant's rejection of Hume's empiricism== Before Kant, it was generally held that truths of reason must be analytic, meaning that what is stated in the predicate must already be present in the subject (for example, "An intelligent man is intelligent" or "An intelligent man is a man").<ref name=Leibniz1996>{{cite book |last=Leibniz |first=G. W. |year=1996 |title=New Essays on Human Understanding |others=Translated and edited by Remnant and Bennett |publisher= Cambridge University Press |page=361 |isbn=0-521-57660-1}}</ref> In either case, the judgment is analytic because it is ascertained by analyzing the subject. It was thought that all truths of reason, or necessary truths, are of this kind: that in all of them there is a predicate that is only part of the subject of which it is asserted.<ref name=Leibniz1996/> If this were so, attempting to deny anything that could be known ''a priori'' (for example, "An intelligent man is not intelligent" or "An intelligent man is not a man") would involve a contradiction. It was therefore thought that the law of contradiction is sufficient to establish all ''a priori'' knowledge.<ref>{{cite book |last=Russell |first=Bertrand |title=The Problems of Philosophy |pages=56–57 |year=2008 |publisher=Arc Manor LLC |isbn=978-1-60450-085-1 }}</ref>
[[David Hume]] (1711–1776) at first accepted the general view of [[rationalism]] about ''a priori'' knowledge. However, upon closer examination of the subject, Hume discovered that some judgments thought to be analytic, especially those related to [[Causality#After the Middle Ages|cause and effect]], were actually [[Synthetic proposition|synthetic]] (i.e., no analysis of the subject will reveal the predicate). They thus depend exclusively upon experience and are therefore ''[[Empirical evidence|a posteriori]]''.
Before Hume, rationalists had held that effect could be deduced from cause; Hume argued that it could not and from this inferred that nothing at all could be known ''a priori'' in relation to cause and effect. Kant (1724–1804), who was brought up under the auspices of rationalism, was deeply disturbed by Hume's [[Philosophical skepticism|skepticism]]. "Kant tells us that David Hume awakened him from his dogmatic slumbers."<ref>{{cite book |last=Adler |first=Mortimer J. |title=Ten Philosophical Mistakes |page=94 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |year=1996 |isbn=0-684-81868-X }}</ref>
Kant decided to find an answer and spent at least twelve years thinking about the subject.<ref name="Bertrand">{{cite book |first=Bertrand |last=Russell |title=The Problems of Philosophy |page=57 |publisher=Hackett Publishing Company |year=1990 |isbn=0-87220-099-X }}</ref> Although the ''Critique of Pure Reason'' was set down in written form in just four to five months, while Kant was also lecturing and teaching, the work is a summation of the development of Kant's philosophy throughout that twelve-year period.<ref>{{cite book |last=Joad |first=C.E.M. |title=Guide to Philosophy |page=361 |publisher=Dover Publications Inc. |year=1957 |isbn=978-0-486-20297-6}}</ref>
Kant's work was stimulated by his decision to take seriously Hume's skeptical conclusions about such basic principles as cause and effect, which had implications for Kant's grounding in rationalism. In Kant's view, Hume's skepticism rested on the premise that all [[idea]]s are presentations of [[sensory experience]]. The problem that Hume identified was that basic principles such as [[causality]] cannot be derived from [[Empirical evidence|sense experience]] only: experience shows only that one event regularly succeeds another, not that it is caused by it.
In section VI ("The General Problem of Pure Reason") of the introduction to the ''Critique of Pure Reason'', Kant explains that Hume stopped short of considering that a synthetic judgment could be made 'a priori'. Kant's goal was to find some way to derive cause and effect without relying on [[Empiricism|empirical knowledge]]. Kant rejects [[analytic reasoning|analytical methods]] for this, arguing that [[analytic reasoning]] cannot tell us anything that is not already self-evident, so his goal was to find a way to demonstrate how the synthetic a priori is possible.
To accomplish this goal, Kant argued that it would be necessary to use [[Analytic-synthetic distinction|synthetic]] reasoning. However, this posed a new problem—how is it possible to have synthetic knowledge that is not based on [[Empirical evidence|empirical]] observation—that is, how are synthetic ''a priori'' truths possible? This question is exceedingly important, Kant maintains, because he contended that all important metaphysical knowledge is of synthetic a priori propositions. If it is impossible to determine which synthetic a priori propositions are true, he argues, then metaphysics as a discipline is impossible. The remainder of the Critique of Pure Reason is devoted to examining whether and how knowledge of synthetic a priori propositions is possible.
==Synthetic ''a priori'' judgments== [[File:KantLecturing.jpg|thumb|Immanuel Kant, lecturing to Russian officers—by I. Soyockina / V. Gracov, the Kant Museum, [[Kaliningrad]] ]]
Kant argues that there are synthetic judgments such as the connection of cause and effect (e.g., "... Every effect has a cause.") where no analysis of the subject will produce the predicate. Kant reasons that statements such as those found in [[geometry]] and [[Classical mechanics|Newtonian physics]] are synthetic judgments. Kant uses the classical example of 7 + 5 = 12. No amount of analysis will find 12 in either 7 nor 5. Thus Kant arrives at the conclusion that all [[pure mathematics]] is synthetic though ''a priori''; the number 7 is seven and the number 5 is five and the number 12 is twelve and the same principle applies to other numerals; in other words, they are universal and necessary. For Kant then, mathematics is synthetic judgment ''a priori''. Conventional reasoning would have regarded such an equation to be analytic a priori by considering both 7 and 5 to be part of one subject being analyzed, however Kant looked upon 7 and 5 as two separate values, with the value of five being applied to that of 7 and synthetically arriving at the logical conclusion that they equal 12. This conclusion led Kant into a new problem as he wanted to establish how this could be possible: How is pure mathematics possible?<ref name="Bertrand" /> This also led him to inquire whether it could be possible to ground synthetic ''a priori'' knowledge for a study of [[metaphysics]], because most of the [[principle]]s of metaphysics from [[Plato]] through to Kant's immediate predecessors made assertions about the world or about [[God]] or about the [[soul]] that were not self-evident but which could not be derived from empirical observation (B18-24). For Kant, all post-Cartesian metaphysics is mistaken from its very beginning: the [[empiricism|empiricist]]s are mistaken because they assert that it is not possible to go beyond experience and the [[dogma]]tists are mistaken because they assert that it is possible to go beyond experience through theoretical reason.
Therefore, Kant proposes a new basis for a science of metaphysics, posing the question: how is a science of metaphysics possible, if at all? According to Kant, only [[practical reason]], the faculty of moral consciousness, the moral law of which everyone is immediately aware, makes it possible to know things as they are.<ref>{{cite book |editor=Charles George Herbermann |title=The Catholic encyclopedia |volume=10 |page=232 |display-editors=etal}}</ref> This led to his most influential contribution to metaphysics: the abandonment of the quest to try to know the world as it is "in itself" independent of sense experience. He demonstrated this with a [[thought experiment]], showing that it is not possible to meaningfully conceive of an object that exists outside of time and has no spatial components and is not structured in accordance with the [[categories (philosophy)|categories]] of the understanding (''Verstand''), such as [[substance theory|substance]] and [[causality]]. Although such an object cannot be conceived, Kant argues, there is no way of showing that such an object does not exist. Therefore, [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] says, the [[science]] of metaphysics must not attempt to reach beyond the limits of possible experience but must discuss only those limits, thus furthering the understanding of ourselves as thinking beings. The human mind is incapable of going beyond experience so as to obtain a knowledge of ultimate reality, because no direct advance can be made from pure ideas to objective existence.<ref>{{cite book |last=Watson |first=John |title= The philosophy of Kant explained |pages=62–72 |publisher=J. Maclehose |year=1908 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=u2kRAAAAYAAJ&dq=Kant+synthetic+judgment+a+priori |isbn=0-8240-2335-8 }}</ref>
Kant writes, "Since, then, the receptivity of the subject, its capacity to be affected by [[Object (philosophy)|objects]], must necessarily precede all intuitions of these objects, it can readily be understood how the form of all appearances can be given prior to all actual perceptions, and so exist in the mind ''a priori''" (A26/B42). Appearance is then, via the faculty of transcendental imagination (''Einbildungskraft''), grounded systematically in accordance with the categories of the understanding. Kant's metaphysical system, which focuses on the operations of cognitive faculties (''Erkenntnisvermögen''), places substantial limits on knowledge not founded in the forms of sensibility (''Sinnlichkeit''). Thus it sees the error of metaphysical systems prior to the Critique as failing to first take into consideration the limitations of the human capacity for knowledge. According to [[Martin Heidegger|Heidegger]], transcendental imagination is what Kant also refers to as the unknown common root uniting sense and understanding, the two component parts of experience. Transcendental imagination is described in the first edition of the ''Critique of Pure Reason'' but Kant omits it from the second edition of 1787.<ref>{{cite book |last=Makkreel |first=Rudolf A. |title=Imagination and Interpretation in Kant |page=21 |year=1995 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |isbn=0-226-50277-5 }}</ref>
It is because he takes into account the role of people's [[cognitive]] faculties in structuring the known and knowable world that in the second preface to the ''Critique of Pure Reason'' Kant compares his [[critical philosophy]] to [[Copernican Revolution (metaphor)|Copernicus' revolution]] in [[astronomy]]. Kant writes: "Hitherto it has been assumed that all our knowledge must conform to objects. But all attempts to extend our knowledge of objects by establishing something in regard to them ''a priori'', by means of concepts, have, on this assumption, ended in failure. We must therefore make trial whether we may not have more success in the tasks of metaphysics, if we suppose that objects must conform to our knowledge" (Bxvi). Just as Copernicus revolutionized astronomy by taking the position of the observer into account, Kant's critical philosophy takes into account the position of the knower of the world in general and reveals its impact on the structure of the known world. Kant's view is that in explaining the movement of celestial bodies Copernicus rejected the idea that the movement is in the stars and accepted it as a part of the spectator. Knowledge does not depend so much on the object of knowledge as on the capacity of the knower.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Chadwick |first1=Ruth F. |last2=Cazeaux |first2=Clive |title=Immanuel Kant, Critical Assessments: Kant's Critique of Pure Reason |page=43 |publisher=Routledge |year=1992 |isbn=0-415-07411-8 |ref=harv}}</ref>
Kant's [[transcendental idealism]] should be distinguished from [[idealism|idealistic systems]] such as that of [[George Berkeley]]. While Kant claimed that [[phenomena]] depend upon the conditions of [[sensibility]], [[space]] and [[time]], and on the synthesizing activity of the mind manifested in the rule-based structuring of [[perceptions]] into a [[world]] of objects, this thesis is not equivalent to mind-dependence in the sense of [[subjective idealism|Berkeley's idealism]]. Kant defines transcendental idealism:
{{pullquote|I understand by the transcendental idealism of all appearances the doctrine that they are all together to be regarded as mere representations and not things in themselves, and accordingly that time and space are only sensible forms of our intuition, but not determinations given for themselves or conditions of objects as things in themselves. To this idealism is opposed transcendental realism, which regards space and time as something given in themselves (independent of our sensibility).|source=(CPR, A369)}}
==Kant's approach== In Kant's view, ''a priori'' [[intuition (philosophy)|intuition]]s and concepts provide some ''a priori'' knowledge, which also provides the framework for ''a posteriori'' knowledge. Kant also believed that causality is a conceptual organizing principle imposed upon nature, albeit nature understood as the sum of appearances that can be synthesized according to a priori concepts.
In other words, [[space]] and [[time]] are a form of perceiving and [[causality]] is a form of knowing. Both space and time and conceptual principles and processes pre-structure experience.
Things as they are "in themselves"—the thing in itself or ''das Ding an sich''—are unknowable. For something to become an object of knowledge, it must be experienced, and experience is structured by the mind—both space and time being the forms of intuition (''Anschauung'' in German; for Kant, intuition is the process of sensing or the act of having a sensation)<ref>{{cite book |last=Angeles |first=Peter A. |title=The Harper Collins Dictionary of Philosophy |page=149 |year=1992 |editor=Eugene Ehrlich |publisher=Harper Collins |isbn=0-06-461026-8 }}</ref> or [[perception]], and the unifying, structuring activity of concepts. These aspects of mind turn things-in-themselves into the world of experience. There is never passive observation or knowledge.
According to Kant, the transcendental ego—the "Transcendental Unity of [[Apperception]]"—is similarly unknowable. Kant contrasts the transcendental ego to the empirical ego, the active individual self subject to immediate [[introspection]]. One is aware that there is an "I," a subject or self that accompanies one's experience and [[consciousness]]. Since one experiences it as it manifests itself in time, which Kant proposes is a subjective form of perception, one can know it only indirectly: as object, rather than subject. It is the empirical ego that distinguishes one person from another providing each with a definite character.<ref>{{cite book |last=Solomon |first=Robert C. |title=From Rationalism to Existentialism |page=21 |quote=In the ''Transcendental Deduction'', Kant distinguishes the transcendental ego from the empirical ego and maintains that only the transcendental ego has these ''a priori'' relations with experience. |year=2001 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=0-7425-1241-X }}</ref>
==Contents== The ''Critique of Pure Reason'' is arranged around several basic distinctions. After the two Prefaces (the A edition Preface of 1781 and the B edition Preface of 1787) and the Introduction, the book is divided into the Doctrine of Elements and the Doctrine of Method:
The '''Doctrine of Elements''' sets out the ''a priori'' products of the mind, and the correct and incorrect use of these presentations. Kant further divides the Doctrine of Elements into the [[Transcendental Aesthetic]] and the [[Transcendental Logic]], reflecting his basic distinction between sensibility and the understanding. In the '''Transcendental Aesthetic''' he argues that [[space]] and [[time]] are pure forms of intuition inherent in our faculty of sense. The '''Transcendental Logic''' is separated into the Transcendental Analytic and the Transcendental Dialectic: * The '''Transcendental Analytic''' sets forth the appropriate uses of ''a priori'' concepts, called ''the categories'', and other principles of the understanding, as conditions of the possibility of a science of metaphysics. The section titled the '''Metaphysical Deduction''' considers the origin of the ''categories''. In the '''Transcendental Deduction''', Kant then shows the application of the ''categories'' to experience. Next, the '''Analytic of Principles''' sets out arguments for the relation of the ''categories'' to metaphysical principles. This section begins with the '''Schematism''', which describes how the imagination can apply pure concepts to the object given in sense perception. Next are arguments relating the ''a priori'' principles with the schematized ''categories''. * The '''Transcendental Dialectic''' describes the transcendental illusion behind the misuse of these principles in attempts to apply them to realms beyond sense experience. Kant’s most significant arguments are the '''Paralogisms of Pure Reason''', the '''Antinomy of Pure Reason''', and the '''Ideal of Pure Reason''', aimed against, respectively, traditional theories of the soul, the universe as a whole, and the [[existence of God]]. In the Appendix to the '''Critique of Speculative Theology''' Kant describes the role of the transcendental ideas of reason.
The '''Doctrine of Method''' contains four sections. The first section, '''Discipline of Pure Reason''', compares mathematical and logical methods of [[formal proof|proof]], and the second section, '''Canon of Pure Reason''', distinguishes theoretical from practical reason.
